executive_summary: Dairy wholesalers have enjoyed stable revenue growth over most of the five years to 2023 as rising prices were accepted by a market with rising dairy consumption and disposable income. Still, because the industry's performance is heavily dependent on commodity prices and retailer practices, the growing trend of vertical integration between manufacturers and retailers has heightened competition between wholesalers and made it more difficult to enter the industry. Automation tech has lifted profit for wholesalers and opened new bases of competition, though, and strong demand has allowed revenue to rise an annualized 2.6% to $117.4 billion over the five years to 2023, despite a decline of 0.5% in 2023 alone.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Dairy wholesalers benefited from rising prices that ushered in heightened revenue. The price of dairy jumped twice through the period, rising 14.6% in 2019 and 16.8% in 2022. High dairy prices are beneficial to wholesalers as long as consumer demand is high enough to justify paying inflated prices at the grocery store. Consistently high prices will send consumers to substitutes and damage revenue, but increasing dairy consumption and rising per capita disposable income secured steady business through price increases.

Thanks to automation systems allowing cutbacks in labor costs, profit has risen over the past five years. New tech has boosted efficiency in production, storage and distribution processes, which has been especially crucial as wholesalers cope with volatile fuel costs. Profit is extremely low for wholesalers, so making use of all tech available to cut back on excess costs is essential to remaining viable.

Dairy wholesalers have faced mounting pressure from alternative products that replace milk or cheese in consumers' diets. Vegan-friendly substitutes like oat milk and almond milk have found massive acceptance among consumers and have fostered a reputation for being healthier and better for the environment than traditional dairy products. This competition has tempered growth and siphoned demand away from the industry.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Despite solid growth in per capita disposable income through the end of 2028, the consumption of dairy products will decline every year over the next five years. This fall in consumption corresponds with growing concerns over the dairy industry's environmental impact and reputation as inhumane. Vegan-friendly substitutes will continue to siphon away demand from the dairy industry, which will lower sales for wholesalers.

In this competitive atmosphere where alternatives to dairy products are finding success, every point in the dairy supply chain will have to contend with low prices to capture falling demand. Lower prices translate to increased per-unit costs, and wholesalers will need to make use of every technology available to operate as efficiently as possible and maintain already-tight profit.

As these trends make dairy wholesaling more difficult, wholesalers will need to compete with each other on a higher level to stay relevant in the supply chain. Retailers and producers will continue skipping the middleman by connecting with each other to boost profit. Value-added services some wholesalers offer, like on-demand delivery, will be very important over the next five years in order to justify their place in the supply chain to retailers.

industry_definition: This industry wholesales dairy products that aren't dried or canned, including butter, cheese, cream, ice cream, milk and yogurt. This industry doesn't include manufacturers' sales branches and offices (MSBOs), where the wholesaling and production of dairy products occur as one undifferentiated operation. Revenue from MSBOs is included in the Dairy Product Production industry (IBISWorld report 31151).

opportunities: Demand from supermarkets and grocery stores
threats: Low Performance Drivers: Per capita dairy consumption

key_trends: Rising dairy prices have elevated revenue. Dairy consumption and disposable income have both risen and allowed these prices to find acceptance on grocery store shelves.

Alternative dairy products are threatening the industry. Substitutes like oat milk are siphoning demand away from the dairy supply chain in favor of healthier, more humane and more environmentally-friendly products.
Revenue will stagnate over the next five years. Falling demand and stagnating prices will heighten competition and push retailers to skip wholesalers and buy direct from producers.
Dairy transportation is monitored. Wholesalers need to use proper refrigeration and handling techniques to avoid disease outbreaks and FDA fines.
The IDFA lobbies for the dairy supply chain. Wholesalers benefit from the organization's networking and educational events, as well as its involvement in the legislative process.
The basics are bestsellers. Shopping list staples like cheese and milk receive reliable demand and make up the largest portion of industry revenue.
Consumers care about their health. Rising demand for low-calorie dairy products is giving wholesalers who can adapt an edge.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Because of contracts granting exclusive distribution rights of certain brands, wholesalers buy dairy products from other wholesalers for resale. Wholesalers often have better relationships with other wholesalers than they do with some producers, so it makes sense for a wholesaler in the West to buy from a wholesaler in the Great Lakes instead of a producer. Wholesalers also need to keep a diverse inventory to meet last-minute needs, which results in backfilling product offerings by buying from other wholesalers. This step cuts down the already-slim margins even further, though, as adding another step in the supply chain can be severely limiting to what wholesalers profit from with each product.

Retail stores rely on wholesalers to acquire the dairy products they can buy for resale to consumers. Independent and national chain supermarkets, mass merchandisers, supercenters and convenience stores account for nearly a third of wholesalers' revenue. Major retailers, like Walmart, have found increasing acceptance from consumers and usually only rely on a handful of big dairy wholesalers to stock their shelves. This segment has declined over the past five years as retail stores continue to skip wholesalers and buy directly from large dairy producers in order to buy for lower prices.

Restaurants, hotels, motels, industrial catering, airlines and accommodation venues all buy dairy products from wholesalers to use in food preparation and service to consumers in various markets. This segment struggled through the COVID-19 pandemic as food service establishments were forced to shut down and lost significant demand amid lockdowns and social distancing guidelines.
Industrial food manufacturers and processors use dairy products as inputs in the creation of frozen meals or other food products.

products_and_services.product_description: Cheese is a staple household item and is also used extensively in food service and hospitality businesses, like fast food outlets and pizza shops, as well as by food manufacturers and processors. According to the US Department of Agriculture's Agricultural Projects report, per capita consumption of cheese has increased in recent years, offsetting declines in consumption from other dairy products and leading this segment to rise as a share of revenue through the end of 2023.

Butter, yogurt, and other dairy products (spreads, blends and powdered milk) only make up a small fraction of revenue. This segment is stable as a share of revenue as the wide range of products included steady the category against declines in demand for one product.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Ice Cream and Frozen Dairy Products
products_and_services.product_description: Ice cream and other frozen dairy products aren't as consistently purchased as cheese or milk, so demand for these products is harder to forecast. Predictably, this segment becomes massively popular in warmer months and drops in the winter. Health-conscious consumers have more and more opted for premium ice cream and frozen dairy products, which are high-margin and bring some breathing room to the industry's tight profit.

Major dairy cooperatives tend to use their members' milk for further processing, but smaller dairy farmers don't process their own dairy and often supply raw milk to a variety of different wholesalers that will then pass the milk on to processors. The raw milk and cream segment's share of industry revenue has fallen following increased consumer focus on the risks of consuming unpasteurized milk.

Wholesalers distribute packaged milk to supermarkets, convenience stores and food service outlets. Milk and cream products are a staple of consumers' shopping lists and include flavored milk, low-fat milk and sour cream. As per capita milk consumption has slightly risen over the past five years, this segment's share of industry revenue has increased in line with consumption.

tier_1_suppliers: Dairy Product Production in the US
Ice Cream Production in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Local Specialized Freight Trucking in the US
tier_1_buyers: Supermarkets & Grocery Stores in the US
Warehouse Clubs & Supercenters in the US
Specialty Food Stores in the US
tier_2_buyers: Food Service Contractors in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Demand from Supermarkets and Grocery Stores
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Supermarkets and grocery stores are the largest customer segment for dairy wholesalers. Demand from supermarkets and grocery stores will rise in 2023, representing an opportunity for the industry.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Demand from Food Services and Drinking Places
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Food service and drinking establishments are a critical market for wholesalers. Demand from food services and drinking places will rise in 2023.

As this industry supplies retailers and food service establishments, wholesalers inherit a reliance on consumers having high levels of per capita disposable income. Per capita disposable income will slightly rise in 2023.
Per capita dairy consumption represents consumer demand for dairy-based foods. Per capita dairy consumption will decline in 2023, posing a potential threat to the industry.
Slight increases in the price of milk lead to higher revenue for wholesalers as long as they can pass along the higher prices to downstream buyers. The price of milk will stagnate in 2023.

business_locations.location_description: The Mid-Atlantic is a great central location for delivering products from the Great Lakes to the Eastern Seaboard, making it the largest region for dairy wholesalers.

High populations in both California and New York make the states prime locations for delivering dairy products to retail clients, so the states have the most and second-most establishments, respectively. These regions have high disposable income and consume some of the industry's most expensive goods.

Despite having a quarter of the population, the Southeast only holds 18.2% of all dairy wholesalers. Other regions present similar issues, and lower populations in the Rocky Mountains and New England deter wholesalers from setting up shop in the region.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The US Food and Drug Administration pays close attention to the quality of dairy products, so wholesalers need to properly transport and store their goods. Dairy wholesalers can be shut down if their products introduce, spread and transmit any diseases, so refrigeration and quality control programs are essential.

The US Dairy Association sets minimum milk prices through the Federal Milk Marketing Order (FMMO) system that ensures farmers receive proper compensation from milk processors or wholesalers in competitive regions. This system categorizes milk products into four classes that require milk wholesalers to report all milk receipts by end use. The FMMO then uses a formula to evaluate a price for each class, and milk wholesalers have to pay at least the weighted-average or blended price of all classes handled. Some regions, like California and much of the Northwest, have their own pricing regulations and don't follow the FMMO, and organic milk is priced much higher than the FMMO baseline.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Despite having a quarter of the population, the Southeast only holds 18.2% of all dairy wholesalers. Other regions present similar issues, and lower populations in the Rocky Mountains and New England deter wholesalers from setting up shop in the region.

basis_points.basis_description: Retailers look for good prices. Wholesalers need to offer competitive pricing with a solid distribution network to back them up if they want to secure downstream demand.
Dairy products compete with substitutes. Alternative vegan-friendly milks have become commonplace, pushing down demand for every part of the dairy industry.
Technology that can connect producers directly with retailers are causing wholesalers to lose their place in the supply chain.

concentration_points.concentration_description: While high competition usually means companies focus on buying out other wholesalers, the existing low level of concentration reduces the incentive to acquire competitors.

While large wholesalers would benefit from absorbing the distribution networks of other large wholesalers, over 75.0% of all industry enterprises employ less than 20 workers and wouldn't serve to substantially boost market share if acquired.
Wholesalers also deal with volatile profit, which reduces the supply of capital and hinders the ability to buy competing wholesalers.

Having an extensive distribution network equipped with modern information systems is essential to avoiding wholesaler bypassing and keeping customers happy. The dairy wholesaling industry especially caters to large companies that can keep up with fluctuating demand and maintain solid relationships with the biggest retailers.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Typical of a wholesaling industry, purchasing costs to buy dairy products for resale account for most of revenue. The volatility of milk prices over the past five years has led to unpredictability in this segment as a share of revenue.

Despite rising per-employee pay nationwide, wholesalers have had to commit less revenue to wage expenses over the past five years. Automation has continually allowed wholesalers to reduce their reliance on labor through online inventory management systems and robotics. Consolidation has pushed this segment down even more, as large companies can take advantage of existing equipment to manage warehousing with little labor.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: While automation is removing some need for labor, paid employees are still required to drive trucks, manage inventory and build relationships with buyers and suppliers.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Dairy wholesalers don't have to deal with a lot of volatility, but changes in the price of milk and other products shift revenue up or down.
Consumer demand for dairy products plays a big role in price as well, as high consumption of milk or cheese will make these products more expensive.

Dairy wholesalers enter into contracts spanning several years that guarantee purchase volumes for producers and stabilize prices for wholesalers. These long-term contracts are great for wholesalers seeking to reduce revenue volatility, but their inflexibility can leave wholesalers with excess inventory or producers with compressed margins.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The rate of new patent technologies entering the industry is low, which limits the potential for innovations. A low rate does not mean that innovations cannot occur, just that the likelihood of some innovation materializing as a threat is lower. However, the concentration of technologies is high in this industry. This suggests that industry operators have exposure to potentially unforeseen areas of innovation.

FAQs.question: How do consumer preferences shift toward expanded health consciousness impact your business performance?
FAQs.answer: As consumers get healthier and more health conscious, they tend to demand more dairy-based products. This may be subject to change as dairy substitutes become more readily available in the market.

FAQs.question: WHOLESALERS MUST TAKE CARE OF THE ENVIRONMENT
FAQs.answer: Dairy wholesalers have to follow Environmental Protection Agency guidelines on air and water pollutants. Ammonia and other chemicals are often used in refrigeration and need to be disposed of properly to avoid heavy fines. Treatments for disposing of ammonia and wastewater are capital intensive, so dairy wholesalers need to ensure they can pay for these added expenses.

FAQs.question: THE IDFA LOBBIES FOR WHOLESALERS
FAQs.answer: The International Dairy Foods Association (IDFA) is the umbrella organization for the Milk Industry Foundation, National Cheese Institute and International Ice Cream Association. Members of the IDFA include dairy producers, manufacturers, wholesalers, marketers and suppliers across the US, Canada and 20 other countries, representing over 90.0% of all milk, cheese, ice cream, yogurt products and dairy ingredients produced and marketed. The IDFA supports more than 3.0 million jobs, including those employed by multinational organizations and single-plant companies, and lobbies Congress for pro-industry regulation.

FAQs.question: How do you adjust your marketing during poor economic conditions?
FAQs.answer: Dairy wholesalers expand the use of promotions, discounts and coupons to incentivize sales, focusing on value-for-money and the health benefits of their products during financial hardship. Wholesalers often emphasize the versatility and longevity of dairy products to appeal to cost-conscious consumers, simultaneously revamping their supply chain for efficiency.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored growth opportunities via mergers or acquisitions?
FAQs.answer: Many major dairy wholesalers have boosted their market share by mergers and acquisitions.

FAQs.question: How does the size of your company impact its profit and growth potential?
FAQs.answer: A relatively substantial portion of dairy wholesalers have only a few employees. Most players in this industry are small, regional wholesalers.

FAQs.question: Has your company enhanced logistical technologies in freezer and refrigeration systems?
FAQs.answer: Advancements in freezer and refrigeration technologies are likely to improve delivery services and expand a company's geographical footprint.

FAQs.question: Does your company use RFID to optimize inventory management and improve efficiency?
FAQs.answer: Dairy wholesalers have been increasingly using RFID to improve efficiency. Employment levels have gone down as a function of increased automation.

FAQs.question: With the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), Canada and Mexico have agreed to raise duty-free limits for US dairy products. How will your company be impacted?
FAQs.answer: The agreement allows greater access to US dairy products to Canadian and Mexican markets, potentially boosting sales.

FAQs.question: Food product wholesalers are subject to wide-ranging regulations from the FDA and other government agencies. What is your company policy on food product safety and compliance with government regulations?
FAQs.answer: Dairy wholesalers are subject to things like pasteurization regulations. Dairy wholesalers prioritize food safety by ensuring products meet stringent quality standards, including correct handling, storage and transportation, to prevent contamination and ensure shelf stability. Compliance with government regulations is mandatory, adhering to the FDA and local guidelines and undergoing regular inspections and audits to ensure proper food safety and integrity procedures are maintained.

FAQs.question: How has input price volatility impacted your purchase costs and selling prices?
FAQs.answer: When milk prices fall, demand from downstream markets expands, pushing up profit. When milk prices strengthen, wholesalers can relegate costs to downstream markets.

FAQs.question: What financial challenges are you likely to face?
FAQs.answer: Dairy wholesalers may struggle with fluctuating milk prices and boosted production costs, impacting profit and potentially leading to financial instability. They can also face challenges in securing sufficient funds for technology upgrades or expansions to stay competitive while facing pressures from the global market. Often, factors like weather and climate change are unforeseeable by this industry.

FAQs.question: Prompt delivery to market
FAQs.answer: Dairy products are perishable goods; therefore, prompt delivery is important to ensure goods are in the best condition for consumption. Companies are starting to invest in technologies like automated trucking as this can optimize productivity and also cut costs.

FAQs.question: Use of specialist equipment or facilities
FAQs.answer: New technologies, like computerized inventory control and truck fleets with refrigeration and freezing capabilities, improve product quality and efficiency.

FAQs.question: Do you have contracts with reliable input providers?
FAQs.answer: It is important to have access to or contracts with reliable manufacturers.

FAQs.question: What indirect effects does per capita dairy consumption have on your business? How do you stimulate demand when dairy consumption is low?
FAQs.answer: Per capita dairy consumption represents consumer demand for dairy-based foods. Dairy consumption is usually stable because foods like milk and cheese are considered staples of the US diet.

FAQs.question: How much demand for your services comes from food service establishments and drinking places? Do you have fixed, long-term supply contracts with these companies?
FAQs.answer: Food service and drinking establishments represent a critical market for wholesalers, as they demand dairy products to serve to customers and use as inputs in food preparation.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor the price of milk? Have you been able to insulate your company from drastic swings in milk prices?
FAQs.answer: A boost in the milk price leads to higher revenue for wholesalers as long as they can pass on the higher prices to downstream buyers. However, consistently high prices will put pressure on profit and can limit demand.
